articles.headline: Financial Wisdom From a New Graduate
articles.snippet: Madison Nipp, 22, a newly minted financial planner, offers some ideas to other recent college graduates.
articles.abstract: Madison Nipp, 22, a newly minted financial planner, offers some ideas to other recent college graduates.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex.

articles.headline: U.S. Signals Willingness to Talks With Cuba
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has proposed high-level meetings on migration between the two countries, reviving a channel that was closed under President George W. Bush.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has proposed high-level meetings on migration between the two countries, reviving a channel that was closed under President George W. Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration signaled Friday a willingness to reopen a channel with Cuba that was closed under President George W. Bush by proposing high-level meetings on migration between the countries.

articles.headline: Ford’s Cheerleader and Chief
articles.snippet: Under the guidance of its chief, Alan Mulally, the company has maintained control of its destiny.
articles.abstract: Under the guidance of its chief, Alan Mulally, the company has maintained control of its destiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that the president of the United States plugs your company’s product, but it happened to Alan Mulally on Tuesday, when President Obama took to the Rose Garden to unveil the administration’s new fuel economy initiative. Surrounded by environmental activists, government officials and the chief executives of the Big Three Detroit auto companies, Mr. Obama declared that by 2016, the car companies would have to produce vehicles that got, on average, 35.5 miles per gallon, a big jump from the current 27.5 miles per gallon.

articles.headline: Contraceptive Sponge Makes a Return to Pharmacy Shelves
articles.snippet: Once the most popular form of over-the-counter birth control for women, the Today Sponge is being reintroduced this weekend by a distributor hoping to reclaim that status.
articles.abstract: Once the most popular form of over-the-counter birth control for women, the Today Sponge is being reintroduced this weekend by a distributor hoping to reclaim that status.
articles.lead_paragraph: The contraceptive sponge has bounced back  yet again.

articles.headline: States Barter Fish and Bullets to Save Money
articles.snippet: The recession has motivated at least 11 states and countless municipalities to split costs and share services.
articles.abstract: The recession has motivated at least 11 states and countless municipalities to split costs and share services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Minnesota was looking for a bargain on the tiniest walleye fish, known as frylings, that the state stocks in some of its lakes. Wisconsin needed more of the longer fingerlings for its fishing lakes. So the neighbors have decided to share fish  Wisconsin’s frylings for Minnesota’s fingerlings  along with hundreds of other items: bullets for the police, menus for prisoners, trucks for bridge inspections and sign language interpreters.

articles.headline: As Dollars Pile Up, Uneasy Traders Lower the Currency’s Value
articles.snippet: The dollar fell to its lowest point in five months on concerns that stimulus efforts may set off inflation.
articles.abstract: The dollar fell to its lowest point in five months on concerns that stimulus efforts may set off inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dollar was on a roll just a few months ago, bounding higher against foreign currencies as investors sought a safe hiding place for their money amid a global downturn. But now, many are rethinking their decision to buy American.

articles.headline: President’s Detention Plan Tests American Legal Tradition
articles.snippet: Determining the constitutionality of President Obama’s proposal for “prolonged detention” of terror suspects without trial is likely to require a national look in the mirror.
articles.abstract: Determining the constitutionality of President Obama’s proposal for “prolonged detention” of terror suspects without trial is likely to require a national look in the mirror.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s proposal for a new legal system in which terrorism suspects could be held in “prolonged detention” inside the United States without trial would be a departure from the way this country sees itself, as a place where people in the grip of the government either face criminal charges or walk free.

articles.headline: In Area Packed With Prisons, a Split on Jihadists
articles.snippet: In the community near the only federal supermax prison, the word Guantánamo elicits emotional questions of politics and safety, and for some, religion and culture.
articles.abstract: In the community near the only federal supermax prison, the word Guantánamo elicits emotional questions of politics and safety, and for some, religion and culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo.  Prison is a way of life here, and always has been. The old territorial prison started it all in 1868 at the end of Main Street, anchoring a community and an economy with its massive tan stone walls and turrets. Generations later, more than 5,000 inmates in state and federal lockups, from minimum security to the so-called supermax, ring the town like a bracelet.

articles.headline: Chrysler Dealers Make Case Against Closings
articles.snippet: Chrysler dealers targeted for closings say they were duped into decisions they thought would help the company.
articles.abstract: Chrysler dealers targeted for closings say they were duped into decisions they thought would help the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The calls from Chrysler officials were coming nearly every day, sometimes several times a day, right through the final weeks before the company filed for bankruptcy. And the message, said Robert Archer, who runs three Chrysler dealerships in the Houston area, was simple: Take more cars.

articles.headline: U.S. Relies More on Aid of Allies in Terror Cases
articles.snippet: Foreign intelligence services are capturing, interrogating and detaining all but the highest-level suspects seized outside of Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Foreign intelligence services are capturing, interrogating and detaining all but the highest-level suspects seized outside of Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States is now relying heavily on foreign intelligence services to capture, interrogate and detain all but the highest-level terrorist suspects seized outside the battlefields of Iraq and Afghanistan, according to current and former American government officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Amid Housing Bust, Phoenix Begins a New Frenzy
articles.snippet: Investors are scrambling to buy low-end houses that are in or near foreclosure, creating a boom in which bidding wars are routine.
articles.abstract: Investors are scrambling to buy low-end houses that are in or near foreclosure, creating a boom in which bidding wars are routine.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Every weekday morning, Lou Jarvis drives the sun-baked suburban streets looking for investment gold: a family that will lose its house in a foreclosure auction within a few hours.

articles.headline: For This Guru, No Question Is Too Big
articles.snippet: Jim Collins is exploring big questions like why some companies succeed and, in his latest book, how successful companies implode.
articles.abstract: Jim Collins is exploring big questions like why some companies succeed and, in his latest book, how successful companies implode.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boulder, Colo.

articles.headline: Elect a Dissident, and You May Win a Prize
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. may let dissidents nominate directors, a good move since companies with dissidents in the boardroom often outperform their peers.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. may let dissidents nominate directors, a good move since companies with dissidents in the boardroom often outperform their peers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER decades of being shut out of the director election process by the Securities and Exchange Commission, shareholders scored a big win last week. The agency is considering making it easier for investors to nominate alternative directors to corporate boards.

articles.headline: It’s Tee Time. Where Is Everybody?
articles.snippet: Some of Bobby Ginn’s developments in Florida look like ghost towns, with empty lots and empty houses. But he is counting on a population boom in the state.
articles.abstract: Some of Bobby Ginn’s developments in Florida look like ghost towns, with empty lots and empty houses. But he is counting on a population boom in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Montverde, Fla.

articles.headline: Guantánamo Closing Hands Republicans a Wedge Issue
articles.snippet: Republicans in Congress started laying plans even before the inauguration to make the debate a question of local safety instead of one about national principles.
articles.abstract: Republicans in Congress started laying plans even before the inauguration to make the debate a question of local safety instead of one about national principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  If there was one thing both presidential candidates agreed on last fall, it was the need to close the prison camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Payoff Over a Web Sensation Is Elusive
articles.snippet: Cashing in on Susan Boyle’s popularity has been tricky for the companies behind “Britain’s Got Talent.”
articles.abstract: Cashing in on Susan Boyle’s popularity has been tricky for the companies behind “Britain’s Got Talent.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Susan Boyle, the frumpy Scotswoman who became a worldwide singing sensation last month, may wind up as the winner this week of “Britain’s Got Talent,” the hit ITV show.

articles.headline: As TV Dwindles, It Still Leads
articles.snippet: At the upfront media sales, network television peddles its annual shows as its audience dwindles. But here’s the thing: network television still has a bigger audience than its media competitors.
articles.abstract: At the upfront media sales, network television peddles its annual shows as its audience dwindles. But here’s the thing: network television still has a bigger audience than its media competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: There we were last Tuesday afternoon at Lincoln Center, media buyers and journalists stapled in our seats for a long afternoon of tendentious speeches from ABC executives about the continued power of network television and the splendor of the shows that were about to unfurl before us.

articles.headline: Ad Revenue on the Web? No Sure Bet
articles.snippet: As advertisers cut online spending, start-up companies look for new ways to make money, like selling real or virtual goods or asking customers to buy subscriptions.
articles.abstract: As advertisers cut online spending, start-up companies look for new ways to make money, like selling real or virtual goods or asking customers to buy subscriptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For anyone with a crazy idea for a Web business, the way to make it pay was once obvious: get a lot of visitors and sell ads. Since 2004, venture investors have put $5.1 billion into 828 Web start-up companies, and most of them are supported by ads, according to the National Venture Capital Association.

articles.headline: Job Losses Push Safer Mortgages to Foreclosure
articles.snippet: As job losses rise, the nation’s real estate disaster is shifting from subprime loans to prime loans issued to those with decent financial histories.
articles.abstract: As job losses rise, the nation’s real estate disaster is shifting from subprime loans to prime loans issued to those with decent financial histories.
articles.lead_paragraph: As job losses rise, growing numbers of American homeowners with once solid credit are falling behind on their mortgages, amplifying a wave of foreclosures.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jack Healy

articles.headline: A Host Defends Her Brand
articles.snippet: Greta Van Susteren, a Fox News host thriving in Washington, is called a liberal but has ties to the Palins.
articles.abstract: Greta Van Susteren, a Fox News host thriving in Washington, is called a liberal but has ties to the Palins.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of cable news, Greta Van Susteren is an outsize personality.

articles.headline: Intel Adopts an Identity in Software
articles.snippet: The Linux programmers at the chip maker are at the center of its foray into netbooks and mobile phones.
articles.abstract: The Linux programmers at the chip maker are at the center of its foray into netbooks and mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Intel has worked hard and spent a lot of money over the years to shape its image: It is the company that celebrates its quest to make computer chips ever smaller, faster and cheaper with a quick five-note jingle at the end of its commercials.

articles.headline: New Justice Could Hold the Key to Presidential Power
articles.snippet: Whoever replaces Justice David H. Souter will be a crucial vote on questions of executive authority, which has become the subject of a profound post-9/11 debate.
articles.abstract: Whoever replaces Justice David H. Souter will be a crucial vote on questions of executive authority, which has become the subject of a profound post-9/11 debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to replace Justice David H. Souter on the Supreme Court, conventional wisdom says his nominee will have little chance to change the court because all the contenders appear to share Justice Souter’s approach on social issues, like abortion rights.

articles.headline: U.S. Captain Hears Pleas for Afghan Detainee
articles.snippet: An American officer, who in civilian life is a policeman, helped find a lawyer for a man held as a suspected Taliban leader.
articles.abstract: An American officer, who in civilian life is a policeman, helped find a lawyer for a man held as a suspected Taliban leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: GHAZNI, Afghanistan  Capt. Kirk Black, who trains the Afghan police in this impoverished province, developed a practiced skepticism about claims of innocence during a decade as a Baltimore police officer.

articles.headline: North Korea Claims to Conduct 2nd Nuclear Test
articles.snippet: North Korea said it had successfully conducted its second nuclear test, raising the stakes in the effort to get the nation to give up its nuclear weapons program.
articles.abstract: North Korea said it had successfully conducted its second nuclear test, raising the stakes in the effort to get the nation to give up its nuclear weapons program.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea announced on Monday that it had successfully conducted its second nuclear test, defying international warnings and dramatically raising the stakes in a global effort to get the recalcitrant Communist state to give up its nuclear weapons program.

articles.headline: Tested Early by North Korea, Obama Has Few Options
articles.snippet: President Obama’s aides say he is seeking a tougher U.S. response than after North Korea’s 2006 nuclear test, but much will depend on Russia and China.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s aides say he is seeking a tougher U.S. response than after North Korea’s 2006 nuclear test, but much will depend on Russia and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing the first direct challenge to his administration by an emerging nuclear weapons state, President Obama declared Monday that the United States and its allies would “stand up” to North Korea, hours after that country defied international sanctions and conducted what appeared to be its second nuclear test.
